metadata.case_name: Income Tax Officer v. Assessee (Hindu Undivided Family)

facts.text: The assessee is a Hindu undivided family.
For assessment years 1944-45 and 1945-46, the assessee filed no returns under s. 22 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, and no notices were issued under s. 22(2).

On April 3, 1948, the Income Tax Officer issued notices under s. 34 for both assessment years 1944-45 and 1945-46 without obtaining sanction of the Commissioner of Income Tax, as it was not necessary at that time.
The assessee filed a return for assessment year 1944-45 on September 4, 1948, showing income of Rs. 4,053, below the HUF taxable limit of Rs. 7,200.
The assessee also filed a return for assessment year 1945-46.
The Income Tax Officer dropped proceedings for 1944-45 as infructuous.
For 1945-46, Income Tax Officer passed order on October 27, 1950, determining net taxable income as Rs. 1,20,603.
Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and then to Appellate Tribunal.

On November 19, 1952, Appellate Tribunal allowed appeal in part, holding out of total profit of Rs. 79,760 from sale of properties, Rs. 33,000 assessable in 1945-46 and Rs. 46,760 in 1944-45. Tribunal observed Income Tax Officer at liberty to take action for 1944-45.
On February 27, 1953, after obtaining sanction of Commissioner, Income Tax Officer issued notice under s. 34 for 1944-45.
Income Tax Officer passed assessment order on June 30, 1953, for 1944-45 assessing total income as Rs. 51,523.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed the order, holding action under s. 34(1)(a) valid and second proviso to s. 34(3) applicable.
Appellate Tribunal affirmed on ground second proviso to s. 34(3) as amended applied.
At instance of assessee, Appellate Tribunal referred question to High Court.
Madras High Court on January 3, 1961 answered whether reassessment under s. 34 completed June 30, 1953 for 1944-45 valid, in the negative.

legal_issues.text: Whether the reassessment under s. 34 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 completed on 30th June, 1953 for the year 1944-45 is valid.
Whether the return dated September 4, 1948 can be treated as a valid return under s. 22(3) of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: The return filed on September 4, 1948 was not voluntary and as it was made in pursuance of an invalid notice under s. 34, must be treated as invalid. No assessment could be made on its basis.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Distinguishable from Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ranchhodas Karsondas

petitioner_arguments.text: The case was one where no return had been filed and income had escaped assessment, so clause (a) of s. 34(1) applicable and second notice valid.
If notice under s. 34 invalid, return in pursuance thereof also bad.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: R. K. Das Co. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax

respondent_arguments.text: Objection to new point on validity of return being urged at this stage, as statement of case admitted notice and return valid.
Return valid; Department cannot ignore it and issue fresh notice under s. 34(1)(a) assuming omission to file under s. 22.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ratio of Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ranchhodas Karsondas; assessment could be made till March 31, 1949 under s. 23 treating return as under s. 22

court_reasoning.text: Appellant not raising new point; statement of case consistent with return not voluntary hence invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Return valid under s. 22(3) even if in response to s. 34 notice.

court_reasoning.text: s. 22(3) permits return before assessment; time limit under s. 34(3) satisfied as assessment possible till March 31, 1949.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Return must be filed before time in s. 34(3) per S. Santosha Nadar and Bhagwandas Amersey.

court_reasoning.text: Not every return under s. 22(3) must be suo motu voluntary; returns in response to notices under s. 22(1) or 22(2) also voluntary but not suo motu.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Return under s. 34 deemed under s. 22(2) and thus under s. 22(3).

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Maharaja Pratap Singh: There assessee had filed prior returns under s. 22; here first return in response to s. 34 but could have been filed voluntarily under s. 22(3) as time not expired.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fresh notices possible there but not directly on point.

court_reasoning.text: Ranchhodas holds return showing income below limit good; cannot ignore. But here determines if good under s. 22(3).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Existence of return cannot be ignored.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects contention that invalid s. 34 notice makes return bad; disagrees with R. K. Das Co.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ITO could have assessed on return treating as under s. 22(3).

holdings.text: The return dated September 4, 1948 is a valid return under s. 22(3) of the Act.
Department cannot issue further notice under s. 34(1)(a) assuming no return filed under s. 22.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ranchhodas Karsondas
precedents_cited.relevance: Return showing income below taxable limit is good return; cannot be ignored to issue s. 34 notice.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Santosha Nadar v. First Additional Income-Tax Officer, Tuticorin
precedents_cited.relevance: Return under s. 22(3) must be before time in s. 34(3).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax Bombay City II v. Bhagwandas Amersey
precedents_cited.relevance: Return under s. 22(3) must be before time in s. 34(3).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar and Orissa v. Maharaja Pratap Singh Bahadur of Gidhaur
precedents_cited.relevance: Invalid notices under s. 34 without sanction; fresh notices possible as prior returns filed.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. K. Das Co. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Held return pursuant to invalid s. 34 notice also invalid; disagreed with.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs filing of returns, notices for escaped assessment, time limits, and validity of reassessment proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Income-Tax Business Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended s. 34 requiring sanction of Commissioner.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Madras High Court's answer that the reassessment under s. 34 for 1944-45 completed on June 30, 1953 is invalid, as the return of September 4, 1948 is valid under s. 22(3) and cannot be ignored for fresh s. 34 notice.
outcome.relief_granted: Reassessment held invalid in favor of assessee.

key_quotes.text: From the language of s. 22(3), we are unable to say that the return dated September 4, 1948, was not a return within s. 22(3).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on validity of the return.

key_quotes.text: It is a little difficult to understand how the existence of a return can be ignored once it is filed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Ranchhodas, emphasizing returns cannot be disregarded.

key_quotes.text: The Income Tax Officer is at liberty to take such action as he may be advised about the assessees liability for the earlier year 1944-45.
key_quotes.speaker: court
